source.1876a116:
# Read training file
X_train = pd.read_csv('../input/learn-together/train.csv', index_col = 'Id', engine = 'python')

# Define the dependent variable 
y_train = X_train['Cover_Type'].copy()

# Define a training set
X_train = X_train.drop(['Cover_Type'], axis = 'columns')
source.4dee839c:
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestClassifier
from sklearn.model_selection import cross_val_predict, cross_val_score

model = RandomForestClassifier(random_state = 1)
model.fit(X_train, y_train)
y_pred = cross_val_predict(model, X_train, y_train, n_jobs = -1)
scores = cross_val_score(model, X_train, y_train, scoring = 'accuracy', n_jobs = -1)
print('Accuracy: {:.4f}'.format(np.mean(scores)))
source.c22676f4:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

from sklearn.metrics import confusion_matrix
from sklearn.utils.multiclass import unique_labels

title = 'Confusion matrix'

# Compute confusion matrix
cm = confusion_matrix(y_train, y_pred)
# Only use the labels that appear in the data
classes = class_names[unique_labels(y_train, y_pred)]

fig, ax = plt.subplots()
im = ax.imshow(cm, interpolation='nearest', cmap=plt.cm.Blues)
ax.figure.colorbar(im, ax=ax)
# We want to show all ticks...
ax.set(xticks=np.arange(cm.shape[1]),
       yticks=np.arange(cm.shape[0]),
       # ... and label them with the respective list entries
       xticklabels=classes, yticklabels=classes,
       title=title,
       ylabel='True label',
       xlabel='Predicted label')

# Rotate the tick labels and set their alignment.
plt.setp(ax.get_xticklabels(), rotation=45, ha="right",
         rotation_mode="anchor")

# Loop over data dimensions and create text annotations.
fmt = 'd'
thresh = cm.max() / 2.
for i in range(cm.shape[0]):
    for j in range(cm.shape[1]):
        ax.text(j, i, format(cm[i, j], fmt),
                ha="center", va="center",
                color="white" if cm[i, j] > thresh else "black")
fig.tight_layout()

np.set_printoptions(precision=2)

# plt.figure(figsize=(24, 24))
plt.show()

source.0d248ff0: The second hypothesis is true with nuances. Only Aspen and Lodgepole pine, Cottonwood/Willow and Ponderosa pine and Cottonwood/Willow and Douglas fir are above the mean.
source.6eefaf34:
# Introduction
The goal of this notebook is to analyse the categorical dependent variable *Cover_Type*
and to know what represents each category in the real life.

The first part consists in a description of all cover types. Specially, which species make up the cover type.

In the second part, a table with all the trees and its characteristics is created. Also a table with the forests and their trees characteristics.

Some hypotheses are declared in the third part.

And in the fourth part, the hypotheses are validated with a very simple Random Forest Classifier model.
source.4baef850: The first hypothesis is only partially true. Only Spruce/Fir and Krummholz prediction errors are above the mean
source.a1ad6e97:
# Aspen

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aspen

**Aspen** is a common name for certain tree species; some, but not
all, are classified by botanists in the section *Populus*, of the
*Populus* genus.

Species
-------

These species are present northern Colorado:

-   *Populus tremuloides* -- Quaking aspen or trembling aspen
    (northern and western North America)
    
![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Aspen_%28Populus_tremuloides%29_02.jpg/256px-Aspen_%28Populus_tremuloides%29_02.jpg)
    
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Populus_tremuloides

***Populus tremuloides*** is a deciduous tree native to cooler areas
of North America, one of several species referred to by the common
name aspen. It is commonly called **quaking aspen**,
**trembling aspen**, **American aspen**, **Quakies**,
**mountain** or **golden aspen**, **trembling poplar**, **white
poplar**, **popple**, as well as others. The trees have
tall trunks, up to 25 meters (82 feet) tall, with smooth pale bark,
scarred with black. The glossy green leaves, dull beneath, become golden
to yellow, rarely red, in autumn. The species often propagates through
its roots to form large clonal groves originating from a shared root
system. These roots are not rhizomes, as new growth develops from
adventitious buds on the parent root system (the ortet).
source.93fc5458: This third hypothesis is false. Cottonwood/Willow and Aspen belong to the same family, but they are clearly differentiated.
source.7eba33f8:
# Conclusion

The fact that some forest types share species, doesn't make have them more prediction errors.

The fact that some forest types are from another division (they have less in common genetically with the rest of forest types), makes them have less prediction errors. Cottonwood/Willow and Aspen have (with Krummholz) the greatest accuracy of the seven categories.
source.6676f1e8:
### First hypothesis
The first hypothesis is that the predictions errors between these pairs of forests are above the mean:
source.4415751a:
# Observations

## Dependent variable
There is no clear line between some types of forests, moreover, there are serious interferences.

These interferences are:

- an Spruce/Fir forest can contain Douglar-fir trees.
- Some Krummholz species are present in other forest types: Spruce/Fir and Lodgepole Pine.

The first hypothesis is that the predictions errors between these pairs of forests are above the mean:

- Spruce/Fir - Douglar-fir
- Spruce/Fir - Krummholz
- Krummholz - Lodgepole Pine

## Family

All the trees of this zone are from only two families. Cottonwood/Willow and Aspen forests are made only of trees of *Salicaceae* family. And the rest of forests are made only of tree of *Pinaceae* family.

The second hypothesis is that the predictions errors, between Cottonwood/Willow and Aspen forests and the rest, are below the mean.

The third hypothesis is that the predictions errors, between Cottonwood/Willow and Aspen forests, are above the mean.
source.7eb165dc:
# Lodgepole Pine

![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Lodgepole_pine_Yellowstone_1998_near_firehole.jpg/256px-Lodgepole_pine_Yellowstone_1998_near_firehole.jpg)

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinus_contorta

***Pinus contorta***, with the common names **lodgepole pine** and
**shore pine**, and also known as **twisted pine**,and **contorta
pine**,is a common tree in western North America. It is
common near the ocean shore and in dry montane forests to the
subalpine, but is rare in lowland rain forests. Like all
pines (member species of the genus *.Pinus.*), it is an .evergreen
conifer.
source.b27a6b83:
# Cottonwood/Willow

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Populus_sect._Aigeiros

***Populus* section *Aigeiros*** is a section of three species in the
genus *Populus*, the poplars. Like some other species in the genus
*Populus*, they are commonly known as cottonwoods. The species are
native to North America, Europe, and western Asia. In the past, as many
as six species were recognized, but recent trends have been to accept
just three species, treating the others as subspecies of *P. deltoides*.

## Cottonwood trees

In northern Colorado there is only one species.

![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Populus_deltoides_%285026724621%29.jpg/256px-Populus_deltoides_%285026724621%29.jpg)

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Populus_deltoides

***Populus deltoides***, the **eastern cottonwood** or **necklace
poplar**, is a cottonwood poplar native to North America,
growing throughout the eastern, central, and southwestern United
States, the southernmost part of eastern Canada, and northeastern
Mexico.

## Willow

![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Bloedel_Reserve_Willow_Tree.jpg/256px-Bloedel_Reserve_Willow_Tree.jpg)

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Willow

**Willows**, also called **sallows** and **osiers**, form the genus
***Salix***, around 400 species of deciduous trees and shrubs,
found primarily on moist soils in cold and temperate regions of the
Northern Hemisphere. Most species are known as willow, but some
narrow-leaved shrub species are called **osier**, and some
broader-leaved species are referred to as **sallow** (from Old English
*sealh*, related to the Latin word *salix*, willow). Some willows
(particularly arctic and alpine species) are low-growing or creeping
shrubs; for example, the dwarf willow (*Salix herbacea*) rarely
exceeds 6 cm in height, though it spreads widely across the ground.
source.7c756305:
# Douglas-fir

![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Aerial_View_of_the_Interior_Douglas_Fir_forests_of_Lake_Country.png/256px-Aerial_View_of_the_Interior_Douglas_Fir_forests_of_Lake_Country.png)

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Douglas_fir

***Pseudotsuga menziesii*** is an evergreen conifer species in
the pine family, Pinaceae. It is native to western North America
and is known as **Douglas fir**, **Douglas-fir**, **Oregon
pine**, and **Columbian pine**. There are two varieties: coast
Douglas-fir (*P. menziesii* var. *menziesii*), and Rocky Mountain
Douglas-fir (*P. menziesii* var. *glauca*).
source.18fcefec:
# Ponderosa Pine

![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Deschutes_National_Forest%2C_mature_ponderosa_pine_and_fir_understory_%2837092575525%29.jpg/256px-Deschutes_National_Forest%2C_mature_ponderosa_pine_and_fir_understory_%2837092575525%29.jpg)

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinus_ponderosa

***Pinus ponderosa***, commonly known as the **ponderosa pine**,
**bull pine**, **blackjack pine**, or **western yellow-pine**,
is a very large pine tree species of variable habitat native to the
western United States and Canada. It is the most widely distributed
pine species in North America.

### Third hypothesis

The third hypothesis is that the predictions errors, between Cottonwood/Willow and Aspen forests, are above the mean.
source.5bb73be5:
# Spruce/Fir

![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Clingmans-dome-spruce-fir-tn1.jpg/256px-Clingmans-dome-spruce-fir-tn1.jpg)

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spruce-fir_forests

**Fir and spruce forests** are greatly affected by slight fluctuations
in climate. Temperature is the primary determinate for spatial patterns
of fir and spruce.The two dominant trees in this type of forest are
*[Picea engelmannii]* (Engelmann spruce) and *[Abies lasiocarpa]*
(subalpine fir). Although thick-barked trees, such as the *[Pinus
resinosa]*, frequently survive fire, the thin bark of spruce make them
more vulnerable. Trees such as the [Pseudotsuga menziesii] withstand much of
the fire due to the thicker bark they have. The scale of the burn
mosaic during a fire, relative to species niche requirements and
mobility, can have major impacts on flora and fauna dynamics.

## Dominant trees:

  - *[Picea engelmannii]*: Engelmann spruce, white spruce, mountain spruce or silver spruce
  - *[Abies lasiocarpa]*: Subalpine fir or Rocky Mountain fir

## Other trees:
  
  - *[Pinus resinosa]*: Red pine or Norway pine
  - *[Pseudotsuga menziesii]*: Douglas fir Douglas-fir, Oregon pine or Columbian pine
  
[Picea engelmannii]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Picea_engelmannii
[Abies lasiocarpa]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abies_lasiocarpa
[Pinus resinosa]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinus_resinosa
[Pseudotsuga menziesii]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Douglas_fir
source.84cea128:
# Krummholz

![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/2016-09-03_17_06_51_Krummholz_Balsam_Fir_along_the_Mount_Washington_Auto_Road_at_about_mile_4.4_%28about_4240_feet_above_sea_level%29_in_Thompson_and_Meserve%27s_Purchase_Township%2C_Coos_County%2C_New_Hampshire.jpg/256px-thumbnail.jpg)

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Krummholz

***Krummholz*** or ***krumholtz*** (German:
\"crooked, bent, twisted\" and *Holz*, \"wood\") --- also called
***knieholz*** (\"knee timber\") --- is a type of stunted, deformed
vegetation encountered in subarctic and subalpine tree line
landscapes, shaped by continual exposure to fierce, freezing winds.
Under these conditions, trees can only survive where they are sheltered
by rock formations or snow cover. As the lower portion of these trees
continues to grow, the coverage becomes extremely dense near the
ground. In Newfoundland and Labrador, the formation is known as
**tuckamore**. *Krummholz* trees are also found on beaches
such as the Oregon coast, where trees can become much taller than their
subalpine cousins.

## Species

These species are present northern Colorado:

- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abies_lasiocarpa
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Picea_engelmannii
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinus_flexilis
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinus_aristata
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinus_contorta
